PHI GAMS PLEDGE NINE DESPITE CENSURE
Student Peace
Poll Proposed
For November 7
Hopkins Mobilization For
Peace Part Of NationWide Move Next Week

Four Points Listed
'News-Letter' Open Forum
To Discuss Resolution Before Undergraduate Vote
A poll of student opinion on antiwar measures will be taken Thursday, November 7, by a Johns Hopkins offshoot of the newly established
National Committee for Student Mobilization for Peace. Previous to the
poll, it is expected that the points to
be voted on will be discussed through
the medium of the NEWS-LETTER open
forum so that an advance toward an
intelligent understanding of the martial situation can be obtained.
The four points to be put before
the undergraduates as worthy of serious consideration, whether or not
they are accepted, are to be put in
the form of a resolution, the exact
wording of which has not yet been
determined. In essence the points are:
1—"To support by every means at
our disposal genuine neutrality legislation to prevent entanglement of
the United States in war—no loans,
credits, munitions or secondary war
materials to belligerents;
2—"To work for the demilitarization of our colleges and schools, especially by assuring the passage of
the Nye-Kvale Bill to make the R.
0. T. C. optional instead of compulsory;
3—"To insist on opportunities in
the curriculum and out for relating
our education to these crucial problems;
4—"To refuse to support the government of the United States in any
war it may undertake."
The National Committee for Student Mobilization for Peace is made
up of the National Student Federation of America, Y. M. C. A. (National Student Council), Y. W. C. A.
(National Student Council), Student
League for Industrial Democracy,
National Student League, Committee
on Militarism in Education, American
League Against War and Fascism,
Interseminary Movement (Middle Atlantic Division), American Youth
Congress, Intercollegiate Council.
At the Hopkins, the poll is being
sponsored, so far, by the Y. M. C. A.,
the N. S. L., the American League
Against War and Fascism, the
NEWS-LETTER, and any other campus
organizations that feel that the four
problems quoted above are deserving
of consideration. It is emphasized
that sponsorship of the poll does not
signify agreement with the points.
It merely means that the sponsors
believe that the points are vital, appropriate, and worthy of the attention of students at this crucial mo(Continued on Page 3, Col. 4)

University Press Issues
Hospital, Math Catalogues
The Johns Hopkins University
Press announced Friday, October 25,
the publication of two catalogues, according to Christian W. Dittus, manager of the Press.
"The American Journal of Mathematics", a quarterly, was the first
of the two publications to be announced. Included on the editorial
board of this ournal are Drs. Cohen,
Murnaghan, and Zariski, all of the
Johns Hopkins department of mathematics.
The "Bulletin of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital" was the second publication,
and contains articles by members of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital faculty.

Guggenheim Fellowships
Announced At University
Students and instructors, of the
age of twenty-five and over are
eligible for one of the Guggenheim
Memorial Foundation Fellowships.
The Fellowship provides for advanced study abroad.
The main qualification necessary
to receive this Fellowship is an
"unusual capacity for research."
The purpose of the Foundation
is to "improve quality of education and the practice of the arts
and professions in the United
States."
The Foundation was founded by
John Simon Guggenheim, one time
United States Senator, and Mrs.
Guggenheim. It annually carries
between forty and sixty Fellows.
Complete details regarding the
acquiring of these fellowships may
be obtained by consulting the notice on the bulletin boards alongside of Dr. Sonneborn's office,
first floor Gilman.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 29, 1935

Oxford Professor
Scheduled To Speak
Dr. James A. Gunn To Give Three
Talks At Hopkins Under Dohme
Memorial Lectureship
Dr. James A. Gunn, professor of
pharmacology and director of the
Nuffield Institute of Medical Research, at Oxford University, England, will deliver three lectures
heard annually at the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine here under the
Charles E. Dohme Memorial Lectureship.
These lectures will be given on November 6, 7 and 8, at 8:40 p. m. each
day in the Henry M. Hurd Memorial
Hall, Johns Hopkins Hospital (entrance 1829 East Monument Street).
The subjects, in order, are "Pharmacological and Therapeutic Properties
of the Harmala Alkaloids and Their
Derivatives," "Reactions of Uterine
Muscle," and "Pharmacological Syndromes."
The lectureship was established in
1916 to promote the development of
a more intimate relationship between
chemistry, pharmacy and medicine.

Bowman Addresses
Presbyterian Union
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of
The Johns Hopkins University, was
the principal speaker at the annual
banquet of the Presbyterian Social
Union, held at the Southern Hotel
last night.
The topic Of Dr. Bowman's address
was "Business of Diplomacy."

Band To Play Saturday
The University Band will make its
initial appearance this year at the
Hopkins-Mount St. Mary's football
game Saturday. The Band will appear
in regular Band uniforms, consisting
of blue sweaters, and white pants.
The Band will be under the direction
of Student Director Ed Ottenheim...r.

AVIATION
Jim Collins — Ace o High-Divers
(Continued from last issue)
Early this year, Jim had been making some sensational power dives
with quirk pull-ups in a new Great
Lakes Navy bomber-fighter type and
had registered some of the highest
stress readings ever made in an airplane. When he finished that job, he
went to work dive-testing another
new fighter for the Navf at the Grumman factory at Farmingdale, Long
Island. The ship mas supposed to be
the "hottest" thing that had ever
been flown. It was the last word in
design, engineering, and performance. Long weeks had been spent in
working out the design and the stress
sheets. Equally great care had been
spent in the fabrication of the ship,
an dthe job was as perfect as humanly possible in the preliminary
stages, but even then there was a
hidden defect.
For three long days Jim had been
doing those long screaming dives for
which he was so famous. Then, just
about twilight one evening, as he was
finishing his routine for the day, he
decided to make one more dive before coming in and landing. It would
be the last one required.
A group of naval observers lined
the tarmac in front of the hangars.
They saw the little silver ship climb
to more than two miles above them
until it was just a speck in the gathering dusk. The shrill whine of its
engine broke the evening stillness as
it headed ,earthward. Faster, faster,
it gathered speed. Jim had slammd
the throttle wide open. The shriek
of the wind increased in a might crescendo like a fire siren. H ewas riding that ship like some wild hellriding Valkyrie. Suddenly, one of the
wings crumpled. The plane, like a
huge bomb, plummeted towards the
ground at over 400 miles per hour.
"Bail out! Bail out!" shouted onlookers excitedly. But no parachute
appeared this time. Fate had decreed that this should be Jim's last

PHI GAMS PLEDGE NINE DESPITE CENSURE
Student Peace
Poll Proposed
For November 7
Hopkins Mobilization For
Peace Part Of NationWide Move Next Week

Four Points Listed
'News-Letter' Open Forum
To Discuss Resolution Before Undergraduate Vote
A poll of student opinion on antiwar measures will be taken Thursday, November 7, by a Johns Hopkins offshoot of the newly established
National Committee for Student Mobilization for Peace. Previous to the
poll, it is expected that the points to
be voted on will be discussed through
the medium of the NEWS-LETTER open
forum so that an advance toward an
intelligent understanding of the martial situation can be obtained.
The four points to be put before
the undergraduates as worthy of serious consideration, whether or not
they are accepted, are to be put in
the form of a resolution, the exact
wording of which has not yet been
determined. In essence the points are:
1—"To support by every means at
our disposal genuine neutrality legislation to prevent entanglement of
the United States in war—no loans,
credits, munitions or secondary war
materials to belligerents;
2—"To work for the demilitarization of our colleges and schools, especially by assuring the passage of
the Nye-Kvale Bill to make the R.
0. T. C. optional instead of compulsory;
3—"To insist on opportunities in
the curriculum and out for relating
our education to these crucial problems;
4—"To refuse to support the government of the United States in any
war it may undertake."
The National Committee for Student Mobilization for Peace is made
up of the National Student Federation of America, Y. M. C. A. (National Student Council), Y. W. C. A.
(National Student Council), Student
League for Industrial Democracy,
National Student League, Committee
on Militarism in Education, American
League Against War and Fascism,
Interseminary Movement (Middle Atlantic Division), American Youth
Congress, Intercollegiate Council.
At the Hopkins, the poll is being
sponsored, so far, by the Y. M. C. A.,
the N. S. L., the American League
Against War and Fascism, the
NEWS-LETTER, and any other campus
organizations that feel that the four
problems quoted above are deserving
of consideration. It is emphasized
that sponsorship of the poll does not
signify agreement with the points.
It merely means that the sponsors
believe that the points are vital, appropriate, and worthy of the attention of students at this crucial mo(Continued on Page 3, Col. 4)

University Press Issues
Hospital, Math Catalogues
The Johns Hopkins University
Press announced Friday, October 25,
the publication of two catalogues, according to Christian W. Dittus, manager of the Press.
"The American Journal of Mathematics", a quarterly, was the first
of the two publications to be announced. Included on the editorial
board of this ournal are Drs. Cohen,
Murnaghan, and Zariski, all of the
Johns Hopkins department of mathematics.
The "Bulletin of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital" was the second publication,
and contains articles by members of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital faculty.

Guggenheim Fellowships
Announced At University
Students and instructors, of the
age of twenty-five and over are
eligible for one of the Guggenheim
Memorial Foundation Fellowships.
The Fellowship provides for advanced study abroad.
The main qualification necessary
to receive this Fellowship is an
"unusual capacity for research."
The purpose of the Foundation
is to "improve quality of education and the practice of the arts
and professions in the United
States."
The Foundation was founded by
John Simon Guggenheim, one time
United States Senator, and Mrs.
Guggenheim. It annually carries
between forty and sixty Fellows.
Complete details regarding the
acquiring of these fellowships may
be obtained by consulting the notice on the bulletin boards alongside of Dr. Sonneborn's office,
first floor Gilman.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 29, 1935

Oxford Professor
Scheduled To Speak
Dr. James A. Gunn To Give Three
Talks At Hopkins Under Dohme
Memorial Lectureship
Dr. James A. Gunn, professor of
pharmacology and director of the
Nuffield Institute of Medical Research, at Oxford University, England, will deliver three lectures
heard annually at the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine here under the
Charles E. Dohme Memorial Lectureship.
These lectures will be given on November 6, 7 and 8, at 8:40 p. m. each
day in the Henry M. Hurd Memorial
Hall, Johns Hopkins Hospital (entrance 1829 East Monument Street).
The subjects, in order, are "Pharmacological and Therapeutic Properties
of the Harmala Alkaloids and Their
Derivatives," "Reactions of Uterine
Muscle," and "Pharmacological Syndromes."
The lectureship was established in
1916 to promote the development of
a more intimate relationship between
chemistry, pharmacy and medicine.

Bowman Addresses
Presbyterian Union
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of
The Johns Hopkins University, was
the principal speaker at the annual
banquet of the Presbyterian Social
Union, held at the Southern Hotel
last night.
The topic Of Dr. Bowman's address
was "Business of Diplomacy."

Band To Play Saturday
The University Band will make its
initial appearance this year at the
Hopkins-Mount St. Mary's football
game Saturday. The Band will appear
in regular Band uniforms, consisting
of blue sweaters, and white pants.
The Band will be under the direction
of Student Director Ed Ottenheim...r.

AVIATION
Jim Collins — Ace o High-Divers
(Continued from last issue)
Early this year, Jim had been making some sensational power dives
with quirk pull-ups in a new Great
Lakes Navy bomber-fighter type and
had registered some of the highest
stress readings ever made in an airplane. When he finished that job, he
went to work dive-testing another
new fighter for the Navf at the Grumman factory at Farmingdale, Long
Island. The ship mas supposed to be
the "hottest" thing that had ever
been flown. It was the last word in
design, engineering, and performance. Long weeks had been spent in
working out the design and the stress
sheets. Equally great care had been
spent in the fabrication of the ship,
an dthe job was as perfect as humanly possible in the preliminary
stages, but even then there was a
hidden defect.
For three long days Jim had been
doing those long screaming dives for
which he was so famous. Then, just
about twilight one evening, as he was
finishing his routine for the day, he
decided to make one more dive before coming in and landing. It would
be the last one required.
A group of naval observers lined
the tarmac in front of the hangars.
They saw the little silver ship climb
to more than two miles above them
until it was just a speck in the gathering dusk. The shrill whine of its
engine broke the evening stillness as
it headed ,earthward. Faster, faster,
it gathered speed. Jim had slammd
the throttle wide open. The shriek
of the wind increased in a might crescendo like a fire siren. H ewas riding that ship like some wild hellriding Valkyrie. Suddenly, one of the
wings crumpled. The plane, like a
huge bomb, plummeted towards the
ground at over 400 miles per hour.
"Bail out! Bail out!" shouted onlookers excitedly. But no parachute
appeared this time. Fate had decreed that this should be Jim's last
